Interview Descriptions: Involved a brief phone interview and was then invited for a face-to-face interview. I received great feedback and submitted my references the next week. A month later and I have heard absolutely nothing from DFCI and I have pretty much given up. After trying for 5 months to get a position and getting very little contact I am not encouraged by their process at all.
Interview Questions: Basic interview questions. Why I wanted the position. A lot of details about my previous job and how I could apply that knowledge.

title: Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA)
Interview Descriptions: Really wonderful interview process. Did phone interview with recruiter and then two in person rounds with hiring manager and other members of the team. Everyone was prepared, professional, and very kind. One of the most well thought out interviews I've done. They didn't try to make it difficult- if you are qualified for the position and your experience is a match, you should do fine.
Interview Questions: Why Dana Farber?

title: Front Desk Receptionist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Stoneham, MA) in Jul 2015
Interview Descriptions:
Interviewed on the phone for 20 minutes and was asked to come in the next morning for an interview with her.  She sounded very interested in me and all my experience.
I arrived 20 minutes early for the interview.  Once she came out and walked me to her office she quickly went over the job responsibilities ( which we had already talked about and it was in the advertised job posting).  She didnt ask me any questions and just asked me if I had any questions. I asked some questions to keep the interview going.  I reiterated that I have done all of the job responsibilities before and how much I enjoy doing them.  Then she quickly said as she stood up " ok then I will walk you out".  I asked her if she wanted my references or all my letters of recommendations and she said "no - I will be in touch by e-mail because we do everything electronically, as she opened her door to let me out.  I got the hint right away she for some reason did not want me - but the day before she was very interested.  Since I am a mature worker - I felt that could have been the reason.  I was very qualified for the position and i was unemployed because my previous employer moved to another State.  The same woman called me 3 weeks later and told me she liked my resume and would like to interview me, I told her she interviewed me 3 weeks ago already and there was dead silence.  Then she said " let me call you back". Of course she never called back.   If your a seasoned worker  be on guard for a job at the Stoneham location.
Interview Questions:
She did not ask me anything once she saw me.
Over the phone she asked me if I was good with computers. 
I told her i have been using different software on computers for years and
Adapt very easy to new software applications.

title: New Patient Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: The people at Dana- Farber want to make you feel good. The whole process of the in person interview was pain less. Most of the question were very straight forward. The question were very must  about how you would deal the different kinds of patients.
Interview Questions: What brings you in today?

title: New Patient Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in May 2015
Interview Descriptions:
After applying online from the DFCI job openings webpage I filled out a questionnaire, I received an email the next day to set up a phone interview. 
From there, they invited me to come in for an in-person interview. After that I waited about a week to set up another meeting with department managers.
Interview Questions:
Describe a time you demonstrated flexibility
Describe a time you took initiative
Describe a time you demonstrated excellent customer service

title: Research Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in May 2015
Interview Descriptions: I applied online through Dana-Farber job system. Then It took about 1 week for processing. I got email to set up call interview with the PI. I did not get offered for the on-site interview.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Physicist/Scientist II (Imaging) Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA)
Interview Descriptions:
Initial Phone interview followed by on-site interview. Was not reimbursed for travel/lodging. 
Everyone was very courteous and nice. I gave a 30 min talk which was very well received, followed by individual interviews lasting 30 mins each. There were a couple of group sessions as well. 
The group consisted of mostly young and friendly professionals - a good environment to be in. 
I had a good feeling I was a favored candidate for the position and everything went perfectly.
Interview Questions: What is your salary expectation?

title: New Patient Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: Interview process was long. I lived in NY. I first had a phone call with HR. Then had to drive MA to have two separate interviews with HR and the manager of a department. Then a few days after that I was thankfully in Florida and had a skype interview Skype otherwise I would've had to have driven back for the third and final interview. It seemed like a bit much for an entry level position.
Interview Questions: What do you know about the position you're interviewing for?

title: Patient Access Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: The interview was easy - I had a phone screening with an HR recruiter. A short while later I had my first in person interview with the supervisor and an HR rep at the same time. The second interview is with the manager. I ended up having the second interview on the same day because the supervisor had a positive impression.
Interview Questions: If you didn't get along with a colleague, how would you deal with the situation?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: Did a direct in-person interview with the lead investigator. Also met with every member of the team, including the hiring physician scientists for about 30 - 45 minutes each. Questions were largely behavioral as my skills had already been accessed. Follow up was made with references.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself. Why science? Why us? etc

title: Scheduler Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute
Interview Descriptions: I got the interview through my staffing agency and went in right away. I was interviewed by two people at the same time. They asked mostly simple questions about why I was interested in the job, my prior experience, and how I would respond to working directly with cancer patients.They talked to me just as much as I talked to them during the interview.
Interview Questions: They asked me to describe a situation where I made an angry customer happy (something along the lines of that).

title: Administrative Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and was called for an interview the following week. The interview itself was just one day and done with three individuals: the Program Manager (direct supervisor), the head of the Department, and the current Administrative Specialist. I met with each for about 30 minutes for a series of basic questioning.
Interview Questions: They gave me the breakdown of a typical day for the position and asked how I would handle it.

title: Protocol Care Administrative Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Dec 2014
Interview Descriptions: Submitted my resume to the medical oncology department and heard back within the same week. Interviewed the following week and was offered the position a couple of days later. Went through the occupational health and HR clearance and began my new position withing about 3 weeks.
Interview Questions: Pretty basic questions. Where do you see yourself fitting in the institute? How do you see this position fitting in to your overall career goals?

title: Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute
Interview Descriptions: After applying online, I received a call from a preliminary interviewer who asked me questions about why I was interested in Dana-Farber. The call lasted 15 minutes or so. The next day I received a call from another interviewer, specific to the position which lasted about 10 minutes. After this I did not hear back and the position showed as filled online.
Interview Questions: What was your previous compensation? Were any of your previous positions part time?

title: Research Fellow/Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute
Interview Descriptions: Web job posting, two interviews, unofficial hire, and two months to get through the Harvard beaurocracy. The process wasn't complicated on my end but there were numerous delays with human resources
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Principal Research Technician Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute
Interview Descriptions: First talked to the PI over the phone. Then, I was called-in for an in-person interview. This lasted about 25-30 minutes. Towards the end of the interview, I was offered the position. I didn't bargain for a higher salary, because the offered salary was more than what I was currently making. Accepted the position, later that evening one of the lab members called and said that I shouldn't have.
Interview Questions: Nothing that I can think of. Interview was fairly simple.

title: Clinical Administrative Support Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Sept 2014
Interview Descriptions: All in all took about a week. Applied online and was called a couple days later by HR. They set up the interview and I went in to meet with the Hiring Manager. After a couple days, I was called and offered the job! Such a great place!
Interview Questions: "How do you handle yourself in high pressure situations?"

title: Stem Cell Lab Tech Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Aug 2014
Interview Descriptions: Applied online - as called in for interview one week later. I met with supervisor in his office, he then took me to meeting room and got the entire department, the supervisor the read scripted questions. A few of the employees were bored out of their minds staring into space.
Interview Questions: I was prepared to talk about my previous experience with patient sample testing, skills in aseptic techniques, and why I was the candidate for the job. My preparation was USELESS! - all they asked were psycho questions - "do you take risks", "what was the most spontaneous thing you ever did", "what was the most traumatic event in your life". At the end the supervisor asked if anybody else had any questions, one lady asked me why I left a previous job, which was the only remotely work related question asked.

title: Cell Processing Technologist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Aug 2014
Interview Descriptions: The interview was just conversational. What I am interested in and what the job involves, any questions about it. Prior relevant experiences. Very large stress put on a 2 year commitment.
Interview Questions: Do you have any experience in a cGMP environment.

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute
Interview Descriptions: I applied through the DCFI human resources website and was contacted for an in person interview with the manager and assistant manager of the clinical research group. After the first round interview, I was invited to return for a second round interview with one of the managers and several of the current CRCs.
Interview Questions: Prepare for questions about working as a team and how you deal with challenging people.

title: CRC Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions:
Invited for interview

One interview with manager and assistant manager
Discussed experience and my career goals
Asked many questions about the position and the ins and outs of clinical research

Second round interview with manager and three current CRCs
Discussed how I deal with challenges and organizational skills
Interview Questions: Many questions about teamwork

title: Clinical Administrative Support Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: It was a very involved process that required several trips.  At the end of the interview process I had sat down with an upwards of 12 people to go over my background and qualifications for the position.
Interview Questions: How do you feel about working with patients that may often times be emotional and stressed?

title: Research Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: I learned of the position and submitted the application online at Dana-Farber Careers website. After about three weeks I was contacted via email to set up a phone interview. The phone interview lasted about 20 minutes
Interview Questions: Nothing unexpected.

title: Clinical Administrative Support Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Apr 2014
Interview Descriptions: First, you will be interviewed by the Managers of all Ambulatory Practice. Then, if they approve of you, you will be asked to interview with a floor-specific Practice Manager. In my case, I was asked to come back a different day to complete a third interview because the practice manager in my second interview was hiring for a position that I did not apply for.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself.

title: Bioinformatics Developer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA)
Interview Descriptions:
Interview process was very hap hazard. The onsite was purely HR but they kept calling again and again with technical questions after the onsite interview.

The only good part was that they make you very comfortable during the interview.
Interview Questions: Very general questions were asked.

title: Associate Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Brookline, MA) in Oct 2013
Interview Descriptions: LONG process where I met with many many people, submitted writing samples and answered many questions. Had to meet with occupational health, get a flu shot and give them my very blood. Intense. I was recruited for this job as well so there was another layer of questions on top of their in house process. Took three months to get hired here.
Interview Questions: So many questions. I think the most difficult thing was having the endurance to get through the day.

title: Clinical Administrative Support Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute
Interview Descriptions: I was set up with an interview for this position through a staffing agency. The interview itself was very short and dry (the recruiter had told me to expect this, as they frequently conduct "rapid-fire" hiring). The interviewer asked me a few basic questions (why I wanted the position, information about my past employment, etc.), and did not offer much personality to help the interview flow. All in all, the entire thing lasted about 10-15 minutes, and I did not get a very good impression afterwards. I wish the interviewer had taken more time and interest in the interview itself, as I feel the short duration and lackluster questioning played a pretty big role in why it did not go very well.
Interview Questions: What do you know about what this job entails?

title: Animal Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Aug 2013
Interview Descriptions: My interviewer first contacted me through email, where she explained the position in detail and set up a phone interview. During the phone interview, which was more difficult than the in person interview, she asked about my past experiences and other questions that seemed unrelated to my current job, such as what was the most admirable thing I've accomplished so far.
Interview Questions: What was my greatest achievement thus far in life.

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Jul 2013
Interview Descriptions: Met with a manager, current employee, and physician. Had a phone screen with HR before landing an in person interview, and worked with HR during the onboarding process. There are required health screenings in order to work at DFCI, but HR helps set up these appointments. TB test, HBV titre, full immunization record. CORI check.
Interview Questions: Strengths and weaknesses, what makes me a good fit for the role

title: Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Jul 2013
Interview Descriptions:
Applied online through the Dana website. Hiring manager contacted me two days later requesting more information. I checked in a week later, and was told they were beginning to schedule phone screens. The next three weeks there were many delays in e-mail communication, but finally an introduction meeting was made. Spent about an hour reviewing my resume and details of the position.
The next week I was asked to send in samples of my work, and the week after that we scheduled an interview. So, six weeks after initial contact I spent the day on site interviewing. I had 7 one hour sessions with 8 different people, it was an extremely long day. Overall I felt that the day went extremely well, and I was very much interested in the position.
This was when the already lengthy process got much longer. I was told it would be two weeks until they made a decision, so when two weeks went by and I had not heard from them I checked in. I was told they needed more time. Keeping the door open, I checked in with them every two weeks, typically not receiving a response to my e-mails. The responses I did receive told me to continue checking in. This was until finally, 10 weeks after interviewing on site, and a total of four months after initially applying to the job.
Dana-Farber sounded like a terrific place to work while I was there, but when I was not the lack of communication did not make it a disappointment to receive an offer.
Interview Questions: If you could create your own hospital, what would it look like?

title: Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA)
Interview Descriptions: Good process, clear and fast
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in May 2013
Interview Descriptions:
I went through the following steps: 
1. VERY brief phone interview (more of a conversation really), 
2. interview with department manager and meeting with a few potential co-workers, 
3. Interview with the research nurse, 
4. Interview with 2 doctors - the head of clinical research in my disease center and the head of the disease center as a whole, 
5. Got a happy call from HR.
Interview Questions: Why do you want this job?

title: Clinical Administrative Support Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Mar 2013
Interview Descriptions: I was chosen after a total of 4 interviews. The first was over the phone. Then I came into meet the hiring manager. Then again to meet with the doctors I would be supporting. The final was to meet with staff I would work closely with.
Interview Questions: Why did I choose to apply there?

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Feb 2013
Interview Descriptions: Brief chat with the recruiter, then with a couple physicians. Was asked about my research background and where I want to go after this job. Spoke to other CRCs and heard back within 2 weeks.
Interview Questions: How do you function in a group

title: Clinical Research Coordinator II Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Dec 2012
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was pretty traditional. I had a phone screen followed by an in-person interview. They asked basic questions regarding my experiences listed on my resume and my knowledge with research and patient contact/
Interview Questions: None

title: Clinical Business Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Feb 2012
Interview Descriptions: I had an initial screening with an HR representative, then a follow-up phone interview with the hiring manager. A week or so later, I was asked to give an in person presentation about a recent project I'd worked. It was about 5-7 slides and lasted about 15-25 minutes, with questions. Then I had individual 1:1 interviews with each person from the panel, each lasting about 20-30 minutes. I was asked about project specific work, as well as some personality questions (i.e., do you think you'd fit in here, etc).
Interview Questions: Do you think you'd fit in here?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Feb 2012
Interview Descriptions: The phone interview was standard interview questions. Why do you want to do research? Why do you want to work for Dana-Farber Cancer Institute? What are your career goals? Please describe your past research experience. Nothing out of the ordinary.
Interview Questions: After the description of the position, the interviewer asked if I had any questions

title: Research Fellow/Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions: Nothing special for a typical research fellow position. Prior communication with lab head as necessary, come in, private meeting with PI, 1 hr prior-research talk, one-on-one meetings with lab members. Also met with some professors from within DFCI who would be potential collaborators. Lunch/dinner with PI in private the same day. Heard back within a week with offer.
Interview Questions: What aspect of our work most excites you?

title: Environmental Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions: I worked as a contracted staff member here and was picked to have an interview for a full time job as a technician.  I was referred highly by my manager here and spent some time with Human Resources to determine what I wanted and where I wanted to go within the business.
Interview Questions: What do you like about yourself?

title: Development Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Brookline, MA) in Sept 2011
Interview Descriptions: It was pretty standard, though it required about three rounds (not including the phone interview). I met with entire team of about 8 people - sometimes individually, other times in groups. Most interviews were pretty average, but a couple were more difficult. I was quizzed on my writing/editing skills, and was put on the spot with a few questions about my understanding of nonprofit development and the department I was applying for.
Interview Questions: Describe a difficult situation in your last job and how did you overcome it?

title: Development Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Aug 2011
Interview Descriptions: Interviewed with the hiring manager than another team member and head of the group. The process was smooth and quick. The interviews were professional and seemed to be well thought out. One of the best processes I've been through.
Interview Questions: Rate yourself in these different categories 1-10: oral communication, written communication, job knowledge, personality, interpersonal skills

title: Pharmacy Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Jun 2011
Interview Descriptions: I had applied on line and immediately received an email to contact them for a phone interview. On the call we scheduled and interview immediately. I met with the lead pharmacist, then was able to spend plenty of time in the pharmacy getting a feel for what they do and the people, could ask questions and vise versa, then went and met with the HR manager
Interview Questions: What skills could I bring to the company

title: Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Jun 2011
Interview Descriptions: I sent an email inquiry for opportunity and the PI happened to be interested. So I was called for an phone interview after a few email discussion. Then an onsite interview was scheduled before I was hired.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Feb 2011
Interview Descriptions: There were lots of interviews, phone calls  and follow up emails. It took awhile to get hired but worth the wait. Everyone was very friendly and informative in the process.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Feb 2011
Interview Descriptions: Initial Contact was per eMail, directly to the supervising PI. The interview consisted of discussions with the PI and meetings with individual members of the group. In addition, a 40min presentation about the PhD project was given with a ensuing discussion. Overall, the interview was very pleasant and felt more like a discussion than a formal interview
Interview Questions: presenting work performed in humans, I was asked a lot about mouse models that could mimic the human disease

title: Clinical Administrative Support Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Jan 2011
Interview Descriptions: I interviewed on 5 separate occasions with 9 individuals for my first position with Dana-Farber. I met with each person individually as opposed to a panel-type of style. The interviews were fairly standard, somewhat more casual than I initially expected in terms of the types of questions asked by some.
Interview Questions: How would you handle difficult patients?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Feb 2010
Interview Descriptions: I interviewed with the PI, gave a talk, and then interview with all the members of the lab. The experience was really good.
Interview Questions: Any, they were very reasonable

title: Departmental Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Dec 2009
Interview Descriptions: I was called in by the department director for a personal interview.  I also met with individual that I would be replacing and training me.  I was given a tour of the department and a lengthy interview.
Interview Questions: "Will you be able to effectively manage the excessive needs of this department while being a single mother?"

title: Research Technician Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Dec 2008
Interview Descriptions: I was hired within the company so my process will be different than those who are hired from outside of the company. It was laid back but professional and I was told of what the job would entail and since I had all of the qualifications I just had to answer a few questions my previous boss's had. I was referred to this new position by my manager of my other job since she knew I wanted to do more and she wanted me to excel more so she gave my name and next thing you know I got contacted by the new PI. Dana-Farber Cancer Institute is professional but they make you feel relaxed during your interview. They see the best in people and have good judgement on who works there.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to switch jobs?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Oct 2008
Interview Descriptions: The interview was like any other postdoctoral interview: you give a seminar on your previous work, then meet the people of the lab and the PI. You discuss the project you would be working on, potential starting date, etc. Depending on the PI, you will discuss your career plans, which he/she may not agree with (for most PIs in the Harvard community, the only way to go is academia; industry or non-bench careers are, according to them, for losers...). You can get the offer at the end of your interview or it may come later. I never get the chance to negotiate salary or benefits; actually, the PI did not even offer to pay part of the cost of the trip...
Interview Questions: What are your career plans. Why this group / Dana-Farber.

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston, MA) in Mar 2008
Interview Descriptions: The interview process seemed a little unorganized.  HR and the hiring department did not seem to be on the same page for much of the time.  There wasn't much room for negotiation and there wasn't much flexibility given.  Somewhat understandable given the non-profit nature or the organization, but also difficult because it's hard to attract talent.
Interview Questions: What was an example of a challenging project you had to work on, what made it challenging, and what did you do to overcome that challenge?
